title: To Bitcoin or not to Bitcoin? A Corporate Cash Question!
summary: In this post, I will bring together two disparate and very different topics that I have written about in the past. The first is the role that cash holdings play in a business, an extension of the dividend policy question, with an examination of why businesses often should not...

title: To Bitcoin or not to Bitcoin: The Corporate Cash Question
summary: The success of MicroStrategy, a company that started in software but has evolved to effectively become a Bitcoin SPAC, has led to a debate about whether companies should be moving their cash from their current holdings (usually close-to-riskless and liquid, low return...
fullContent: The success of MicroStrategy, a company that started in software but has evolved to effectively become a Bitcoin SPAC, has led to a debate about whether companies should be moving their cash from their current holdings (usually close-to-riskless and liquid, low return investments) to bitcoin. I believe that as a general principle, this is a bad idea for many reasons - it does not have the shock absorber feature that cash is supposed to have, it steps on a company's business narrative, corporate managers are terrible traders (bitcoin or any other investment) and it opens the door to fraud and self-dealing. There are four exceptions - companies that are perceived to have a bitcoin savant at their helm (a la MicroStrategy), companies who are in the bitcoin business (PayPal & Coinbase), companies in countries with failed currencies and companies that have failed business models but have, through accident or by design, become meme stocks (AMC & Gamestop). Even with these exceptions, there h
